facts.fact: Despite its English name, Bulbasaur's design is based on a frog, not a dinosaur!

Due to the censorship that prevents Pok√©mon with offensive nicknames being traded on the GTS, an Ivysaur (or any of its evolutionary line) with an English name couldn't be traded on the GTS without a nickname in Pok√©mon Black and White. This is because, the word 'Sau' in German means 'female pig,' a word commonly used as an insult!
Venusaur and its evolutionary relatives share their category with Sunkern! They are all known as the Seed Pok√©mon!
Charmander's eyes are blue (teal)!
In episode 429 of the anime, Elina's Charmeleon goes on a date with a wild Wartortle, wherein the Charmeleon uses Water Gun to impress the Wartortle!
Prior to Generation VI, Charizard and Rhyhorn shared the same cry! (Example: https://youtu.be/BiHxE6bZQb4)
While Squirtle typically walks on its two short legs, it has been shown to run on all fours in Super Smash Bros. Brawl!
Wartortle's feathery tail may be a reference to Japanese legends of the minogame (Ëìë‰∫Ä), a turtle which lived for 10,000 years and grew a tail made of seaweed!
Despite being based neither on a crustacean nor a marine mollusk, Blastoise is known as the Shellfish Pok√©mon!
The antenna on Caterpie's head canonically STINKS!
In the almost every Pok√©mon game, the TCG, and promotional artwork, Metapod's eyes are white. In the anime, however, they are yellow, and in Colosseum and XD they are blue!
In Generation IV only, Butterfree can learn a Dragon-type move: Twister, via Move Tutor!
Weedle is the only Pok√©mon that cannot legitimately know any Normal-type move!

Kakuna has arms! Seen only in its Red and Blue sprite and on a rare Sugimori-drawn 'Pocket Monsters' Bandai card, its arms are commonly mistaken to be a sprite error or simply thought not to exist! https://bulbapedia.bulbagarden.net/wiki/File:Bandai_Kakuna_card.jpg

According to all known laws of aviation, there is no way a Beedrill should be able to fly. It's wings are too small to get its fat little body off the ground. The Beedrill, of course, flies anyway, because Beedrill don't care what humans think is impossible.
In the anime, Pidgey is often erroneously depicted with four talons on each foot, as opposed to three!
In some games, the Pok√©dex states that Pidgeotto 'will fiercely peck at any intruder.' However, Pidgeotto is unable to learn Peck!
Pidgeot has a mullet! Business in the front, party in the back, baby! üòé
In the Pok√©mon Red and Blue beta, Rattata was originally known as Rattatak!
Raticate is the only Pok√©mon that shares its National Pok√©dex number, 20, with the level at which it evolves from its pre-evolved form!
Spearow preys on various forms of Bug-type pok√©mon, as well as Sunkern! Wait‚Äî üò≥ SUNKERN!? That's not fun. üò† WHO WROTE THESE!? @miggtorr!???!??

Fearow is able to fly using its massive wings and attack using its sharp beak. This is because it has massive wings that are large and a sharp beak that is really pointy! Through the use of these unique anatomical features, namely its large wings and pointed beak, it is able to fly and hunt for pray. Also its shiny is blue in Pok√©mon Stadium 2.
In early official art of Ekans, namely the Sugimori watercolors, all of the bands on its body were colored yellow instead of just the one on its neck. This was changed in later depictions of Ekans.
In its Gen I sprite, Arbok had markings on the back of its head in addition to those on the front.

Pikachu originally had a second-stage evolution, after Raichu, named Gorochu which would have had two horns and fangs. Ken Sugimori stated that while there was nothing wrong with its appearance, it was nonetheless omitted from Pok√©mon Red and Green, as the staff found that the game was more balanced without it. Moreover, some Pok√©mon originally designed to evolve twice were changed to evolve only once due to limited game space.

In Pok√©mon Red and Blue, there is a Scientist at the Pok√©mon Lab in Cinnabar Island who will trade you an Electrode for a Raichu. If the player talks to him after the trade, he will mention that the Raichu evolved! This is due to a translation error (in Japanese Blue versions he trades a Graveler for a Kadabra).
The pattern on Sandshrew's hide makes it look like it's made of sandstone bricks! This pattern was absent from Sandshrew's initial design, so its Red, Blue, and Green sprites look much more scaley.
In the Pok√©mon Red and Blue beta, Sandslash's original name was 'Sandstorm'.
Nidoran‚ôÄ is the only Pok√©mon that loses the ability to breed upon evolution. Neither Nidorina nor Nidoqueen can produce eggs!
In Gen I only, Nidorina can learn Bubblebeam!
In a 1996 Japanese publication by Creatures, Inc. titled 'Pocket Monsters Encyclopedia,' Nidoqueen and Nidorina's inability to lay Eggs was established before breeding became a mechanic in the games!
When traded into a Gen II game from a Gen I game, a Nidoran‚ôÇ will always arrive holding a TM43 (Detect)!
Unlike Nidorina and Nidoqueen, Nidorino is capable of producing eggs, belonging to both the Monster and Field egg groups.

Nidoking isn't actually a real 'King' of any country or nation-state, fictional or otherwise. The 'king' in its name is actually an abbreviated form of 'Burger King!' ...wait‚Äîwhat?? Who wrote this!? @miggtorr!!?? üò†
While Pikachu may nowadays be the worldwide mascot of the Pok√©mon franchise, Clefairy was an early contender for the position during the franchise's infancy.

In the Pok√©mon Red and Green beta, Clefable's name was Ariala. This sounds very close to the word 'areola,' the clinical term for nipple, so it's a good thing they changed it! (Incidentally, this linguistic phenomenon didn't stop them from naming Magmar 'Boober' in Japan).
Vulpix is born with only a single, white tail that splits into six as Vulpix grows!
Ninetales is actually Naruto.
Due to an oversight, Jigglypuff appears purple (instead of pink) in the battle against Gengar in the intro of Pok√©mon Blue (including the Japanese version)!
In its earlier appearances (Gens I-II), Wigglytuff's white stomach did not always extend above its mouth as it does in modern rendition of this Pok√©mon!
Since Zubat is eyeless, in Pok√©mon Legends: Arceus, Alpha Zubats don't include glowing red eyes!
The only core series games to depict Golbat's tongue were Pok√©mon Red and Blue!
Oddish's name may be derived from the words 'odd' and 'radish!'
Gloom is the only dual-type Pok√©mon that can evolve into a single-type Pok√©mon‚ÄîBellossom!
Although Vileplume has the Chlorophyll Ability, the Rafflesia family of plants that it is based on do not contain chlorophyll!
Paras's normal and shiny colors were reversed from Gen II to Gen III and have remained the same ever since!
When Parasect evolves from Paras, the tochukaso mushroom on its back takes complete control of the host and does all the thinking!
In Pok√©mon Crystal only, Venonat's eyes flash during its sprite animation!
In early official art, Venomoth had yellow spots on the back of its wings! These spots were removed when later official artwork was released.
In Pok√©mon Mystery Dungeon: Red Rescue Team and Blue Rescue Team, a Diglett you encounter mentions having feet!
Dugtrio has the highest base Speed stat of all Ground-type Pok√©mon, but of all Pok√©mon to have the highest Speed stat of their respective types, Dugtrio is the slowest!
The only time Meowth is depicted on all fours in the games is in Pok√©mon HGSS: when the player places Meowth as the first Pok√©mon in their party, Meowth will walk on four legs behind the player!
In German, Persian's name is 'Snobilikat,' from the words 'snob,' 'nobilis,' (Latin for noble) and 'Katze' (cat)!

Junichi Masuda revealed that Psyduck was considered for the role of Pikachu's counterpart in Pok√©mon: Let's Go, Pikachu! and Let's Go, Eevee! instead of Eevee, but it was ultimately not chosen due to it being deemed too similar in color to Pikachu!
Although Golduck possesses psychic abilities, it is only a pure Water-type!
Mankey's name, 'Mankey,' comes from the English word 'monkey'! This is because it resembles a monkey!
A Primape caught in Gen I will be holding the Gold Leaf item when traded to a Gen II game! This rare item seemingly has no use; it can only be sold for a paltry ‚ÇΩ1000.
Growlithe's forepaws have two visible claws, while its hind paws have three toes each!
Arcanine's Japanese name is „Ç¶„Ç§„É≥„Éá„Ç£ (Windy). This is a reference to the Pok√©mon's notorious flatulence! üçë üí®
Prior to Gen VI, Poliwag and Ditto had the same cry! (Compare Polywag: https://youtu.be/UzNT7nT62AE, Ditto: https://youtu.be/Hmd_9hKTKsM)

In Pok√©mon Red, Green, Blue, Gold, Silver, Crystal, Ruby, & Sapphire, Poliwhirl is depicted with fingers on his hands! In Pok√©mon Yellow, as well as every main-series game from Emerald onward, however, his hands look like mittens!
In some illustrations, notably its Gen II sprites, Poliwrath is depicted with four fingers instead of three!
In Gen I only, Abra can learn the move Skull Bash.
The symbols on Kadabra's forehead and abdomen appear to be references to 'Zener cards,' a small deck of symbols used in experiments to test for ESP and clairvoyance in the early 1930s!

Alakazam and its pre-evolved form, Kadabra, are the only known Pok√©mon capable of learning the move Kinesis! While this move drops the target's Accuracy by 1 stage, it only has an 80% chance to hit, making it one of the worst moves in the entire franchise!

Before the release of the English versions of Pok√©mon Red and Blue, Machop was known as 'Kara-Tee.' Sounds kinda racist tbh, but what to I know? I'm just a robotic sunflower. ü§ñ BEEP BOOB BOPP ü§ñ
Machoke has been featured on 20 different cards since it debuted in the Base Set of the Pok√©mon Trading Card Game!
When Machamp evolves from Machoke it gains ten fingers, but loses six toes!
In Episode 600 of the anime, a wild Bellsprout is seen using the move Absorb, but Bellsprout cannot learn Absorb in any main series game!

Weepinbell's Gold and Silver sprites are almost identical, with its left leaf pointing up in Gold and down in Silver. Its mouth is also slightly rotated. Incidentally, Pok√©mon Crystal uses the Gold sprite as the basis for its sprite and subsequent animation.
The blue lips in Victreebel's shiny coloration may reference how the rims of certain pitcher plants glow blue under UV light!
In Pok√©mon XD: Gale of Darkness, Tentacool's shiny has blue jewels, green tentacles, and light blue eyes!
In the Pok√©mon Red and Blue beta, Tentacruel was originally known as Manowar, after the deadly 'Portuguese Man o‚Äô War' jellyfish!
The number of Tentacruel's tentacles has varies across its various depictions over the years, but its current 3D model has ten tentacles!
Geodude's evolutionary line is the only three-stage evolutionary line in which all members have a regional form!
Upon evolving, Kantonian Graveler loses three fingers and gains four toes!
Golem's name is based on the golem of Jewish folklore, an anthropomorphic, animated being created entirely from inanimate matter, usually clay or mud!
Ponyta's shiny doesn't receive its signature blue mane until Gen III.
Galarian Rapidash's category, Unique Horn, is a pun on the word 'unicorn'!
No Slowpoke has ever been seen using an attack in the anime!
In Pok√©mon Silver, Slowpoke's sprite reveals in belly, but the stripes on its belly are only shown in the Japanese version of the game!
Slowbro debuted in the Fossil expansion of the Pok√©mon Trading Card Game!
Magnemite was designed by Ken Sugimori, based on an idea by Satoshi Tajiri!
The screws on Magnemite and Magneton are Phillip's Head screws!
In Gens I-III of the main line games, Magneton was depicted with 9 screws on its body. Beginning in Gen IV, however, its sprite and subsequent 3D models now feature only 7 screws!
Magneton and its pre-evolved form were the first Pok√©mon to ever change types with the progress of generations!

In the Pok√©mon Gold and Silver Spaceworld '97 demo, Farfetch'd had an evolution, known as „Éû„ÉÄ„Éº„É† (MadƒÅmu), that was scrapped in the final release of the games! Sirfetch'd was not based on this scrapped evolution.
Male Doduo have black necks, while female Doduo have beige necks!
Doduo's shiny didnt gain its green hue until Gen III (in Gen II it was golden)!
Dodrio is the only Pok√©mon whose National Pok√©dex number is the whole number portion of its weight in kilograms, 85!
Dodrio and Doduo are the only Flying-type Pok√©mon to consist only of a head and legs!
Seel is the only non-Ice-type Pok√©mon that can have Ice Body as its Ability!
According to the Pok√©mon Ultra Sun dex entry, Dewgong consider Wishiwashi a delicacy!
Alolan Muk's rainbow colors are based on a phenomenon called 'thin-film interference,' wherein a spectrum of colors is reflected from a thin layer of oil floating on top of water!
Grimer's name in French is Tadmorv, which comes from the phrase 'tas de morve,' meaning 'pile of snot'!
Muk pronounced backwards is‚Äî hey wait a sec, who wrote this!? üò† @miggtorr?!?
Muk's name in French is Grotadmorv, a contraction of 'gros Tadmorv,' meaning 'Big Grimer,' or‚Äîmore literally‚Äî'big pile of snot'!
Shellder swims backward by opening and closing its two shells!
In Pok√©mon Red and Blue only, Cloyster's shell depicted opening vertically‚Äîlike a traditional clam‚Äîin its front sprite!
Pok√©mon Yellow was the first game in which Gastly's face was depicted with a well-defined edge!
The presence of Ghost pok√©mon implies the existance of an afterlife in the pok√©mon universe!
Gastly has a special attack stat of 100, quite high for a non-evolved pok√©mon!
In Gens I-V, Haunter's hands glowed red, while shiny Haunter's hands glowed blue! This feature was removed in Gen VI.
The Pok√©mon Moon dex entry for Gengar states that it used to be human, implying that humans can become pok√©mon after death or otehr circumstances!
Onix is the heaviest and tallest Pok√©mon that still has the ability to evolve!
Drowzee is based on the Japanese myth of the baku, creatures said to devour nightmares! More info on the Japanese Baku: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baku_(mythology)
Hypno's card art from the Aquapolis TCG expansion set depicts a Hypno using Dream Eater on a sleeping human!
Krabby has only four legs!
Of Kingler's two claws, the left one is the larger of the two EXCEPT in the Gen I games, where its right claw is larger!
Kingler's front sprite from Pok√©mon Red and Blue depicts both claws being the same size!
In Gens I & II, Voltorb and Electrode learn no Electric-type moves via level-up!
Voltorb has the lowest base Attack stat of all Electric-type Pok√©mon: 30!

In episode 113 of the anime, the 'Who's that Pok√©mon?' silhouette featured a black circle with two antennae-like filaments arcing out. The circle was an Electrode bearing a surprised expression and the filaments were actually its eyebrows raised in shock! (https://youtu.be/cDqtX-o2L8M)
Exeggcute's shiny was originally greenish-yellow! It was changed to be golden in Gen III!
Exeggutor is a rare example of a Pok√©mon that is capable of de-evolution because when one of its heads grows too big, it falls off, becoming an Exeggcute in the process!
Cubone's face is partially revealed on a rare Sugimori-drawn 'Pocket Monsters' Bandai card! Example: https://bulbapedia.bulbagarden.net/wiki/File:Bandai_Cubone_card.jpg
Alolan Marowak is the only dual-type Pok√©mon that shares no types with its pre-evolution!
In Gen II only, Hitmonlee's arms and legs are darker than his body!
Hitmonchan and Hitmonlee are the only Pok√©mon that were introduced as not being evolutionary relatives but later became part of the same evolutionary family!
Hitmonchan can learn almost every punching move, but it can't learn Sucker Punch. This is because Hitmonchan is an honorable fighter who doesn't take cheap shots!
In Goldenrod Tunnel, there is a Pok√© Maniac who‚Äîbefore battling‚Äîsays his Pok√©mon just got a haircut! His only Pok√©mon is a Lickitung. This implies Lickitung is capable of growing hair.

Koffing's front sprite in Pok√©mon Crystal is similar to the one in Pok√©mon Gold, except without the surrounding gas. This makes Koffing one of the few pok√©mon to have a different front sprite for each Gen II game!

Weezing's shiny has undergone several revisions since it was introduced, especially regarding the color of the skull-and-crossbones patterns on its body! The patterns have been yellow, white, or pink, depending on the game!
In Pok√©mon Stadium 2 only, Shiny Rhyhorn is depicted with a neon green tongue!
In Gen I only, Rhydon can learn Bubblebeam!
According to interviews with Ken Sugimori, Rhydon was one of the first Pok√©mon ever created!
Chansey is tied with Happiny for the lowest base Attack and Defense stats of all Pok√©mon: 5!
In Pok√©mon Gold and Silver only, Tangela's non-shiny sprite was a bright cyan!
Despite obvious anatomical differences from its mother, Kangaskhan's baby has never been an official baby Pok√©mon!
Horsea's artwork from Pok√©mon Red and Blue depicted it with two fins instead of one! Example: https://bulbapedia.bulbagarden.net/wiki/File:116Horsea_RB.png
Seadra's EV Yield (1 Defense and 1 Special Atk) is unique among all pok√©mon!
When traded into a Gen II game from a Gen I game, a Goldeen will always arrive holding a TM33 (Ice Punch)! Incidentally, Goldeen cannot learn Ice Punch.
Seaking debuted in the Jungle expansion of the Pok√©mon Trading Card Game!
The front sprite for Staryu in Pok√©mon Yellow depicts it horiztonatlly, either lying down or floating!
In Gen II Starmie can learn attract, but it has no effect since Starmie is classified as 'gender unknown.'

Translator Nob Ogasawara was wary about Mr. Mime's English name during localization, saying, 'If they make sequels and they give genders to Pok√©mon, we're going to be hooped!' Mr. Mime has an 50/50 Male-Female gender distribution.
The Mr. Mime obtained through an in-game trade in Pok√©mon Red and Blue was nicknamed Marcel! The same Mr. Mime is nicknamed Miles in Yellow, and Mimien in FireRed and LeafGreen.
In Gen II only, in addition to its limbs, Shiny Scyther's wings were orange!

Between Gens I and II, Game Freak redesigned Jynx to be less racist by making its face dark purple instead of black. Did it help!? Not really, but what do I know!? I'm just a robotic sunflower! ü§© üôÉ ü§ß ü§ñ BEEP BOOB BOPP ü§ñ

In its original artwork, Electabuzz has four fingers on each hand. In the anime and subsequent artwork, each hand has five fingers. In Pok√©mon Stadium and Pok√©mon Stadium 2, it is depicted with six fingers on each hand (five fingers and one thumb)!
Magmar's Japanese name is Boober, hehehe.
Magmar debuted in the Base Set of the Pok√©mon Trading Card Game!
In Gens I and VII, Magmar can learn Teleport!

On a rare Sugimori-drawn 'Pocket Monsters' Bandai card, Pinsir is shown performing a Guillotine attack with its pincers lowered! Example: https://bulbapedia.bulbagarden.net/wiki/File:Bandai_Pinsir_card.jpg

In episode 35 of the anime, Ash catches a herd of 30 Tauros. This episode was banned outside of Asia, however, due to the prolofic use of guns, leaving many international viewers wondering where and when he caught all the tauros!
Magikarp is the only Pok√©mon in Pok√©mon Scarlet and Violet that cannot use Tera Blast!
In addition to the Water 2 egg group, Magikarp also belongs to the Dragon egg group!

Despite being a Flying-type, Gyrarados could not learn any Flying-type moves until HGSS, where it could learn Bounce via move tutor! It would not gain access to another flying move until being able to learn Hurricane in Gen VII.
Gyarados's original design resembled an massive, eyeless leech! Example: https://twitter.com/okp108/status/1075154559947829248/photo/2
In the documents for Satoshi Tajiri's Capsule Monsters pitch, Lapras was drawn without its curly ears! Example: https://bulbapedia.bulbagarden.net/wiki/File:Early_Lapras_sketch.png
In its Generation I official Sugimori watercolor‚Äîand in Pok√©mon Adventures‚ÄîLapras was depicted with teeth! Example: https://bulbapedia.bulbagarden.net/wiki/File:131Lapras_RB.png

Ditto had a scrapped evolution in the Pok√©mon Gold and Silver Spaceworld '97 demo named „Ç¢„Éã„É¢„É≥ (Animon), which evolved from Ditto using a Metal Coat! Example: https://bulbapedia.bulbagarden.net/wiki/File:Spr_2d_188.png

Unlike other Eevee, in Pok√©mon: LGPE, the partner Eevee has sexual dimorphism: Male partner Eevee look the same as all other Eevee, but female partner Eevee have a unique flower-shaped tail pattern! In Gen VIII, this gender difference was applied to all female Eevee.
Eevee made its TCG debut in the Jungle expansion of the Pok√©mon Trading Card Game!
In terms of male human and female Pok√©mon breeding, Vaporeon is the most comp‚Äî ...I'm not reading this. Who added this to the list of facts!? @miggtorr!??!?!??!?? üò†
In Gen 3 only, Vaporeon's normal sprite is closer to a cyan color than the light blue we are used to today!
In Gen I, the fin on Vaporeon's head continued down it's spine. This fin is visible in the back sprites in Pok√©mon Red, Green, Blue, and Yellow!
The artwork for Light Jolteon from the Neo Destiny TCG Expansion also features Togepi and Rattata!
Flareon's base attack is 130, but it lacked any physical STAB moves until Fire Fang in Gen IV (after the Physical and Special Split).
In Pok√©mon Scarlet & Violet, Flareon is the only Eeveelution that is not able to swim, standing on a platform when sent out in battle above water!
Porygon's evolutionary line is the only three-stage evolutionary line whose members were all considered fully evolved during their respective debut generations!
Porygon is the only Pok√©mon that evolves by trade twice!
Porygon is the only Pok√©mon in a three-stage evolutionary line that does not require leveling up to trigger any of its evolutions! One can legally obtain a Porygon-Z at level 1!
In Gen II only, Omanyte's shiny was gray, not purple!
In the artwork for Dark Omastar in the Neo Destiny TCG Expansion, it is depicted attacking the viewer's face!
Kabuto has two pairs of eyes, the two on its back and the two red ones underneath!
Kabuto's design seems to be a blend of a trilobite and a horseshoe crab!

Kabutops has a scientific name, 'Kabutops maximus' (Latin: Largest Kabutops), which was stated in episode 163 of the anime! The only other Pok√©mon with a known scientific name is Oddish, styled 'Oddium wanderus!'
In the Pok√©Rap, Aerodactyl comes after Tentacruel and before Omanyte!
Aerodactyl inspired the real-life the naming of 'Aerodactylus,' a genus of pterosaur!
In the Pok√©mon Stadium series, Snorlax open their eyes when they faint!
In Pok√©mon Gold & Silver, Snorlax's sprite colors are maroon and beige. In Pok√©mon Crystal, however, the maroon is changed to a darker brown color.
In Gen II only, the pads on shiny Snorlax's feet are blue!
Articuno's name comes from the word 'Arctic' and the Spanish word 'Uno (One)!
Anatomically, Articuno is very similar to the white-throated magpie-jay! (Example: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White-throated_magpie-jay)
When traded into a Gen II game from a Gen I game, a Zapdos will always arrive holding Bright Powder!
Moltres's name is a double pun: 'Molt-' comes from 'molten' (liquefied by heat) and 'molt' (shedding old feathers while producing new ones)!
In Pok√©mon Red, Blue, and Green, Dratini had lines on its belly!
Although Dragonair can moves through the air unaided, it has been seen making its wings grow larger when flying! Example: https://bulbapedia.bulbagarden.net/wiki/File:Lana_Dragonair.png

On a rare Sugimori-drawn 'Pocket Monsters' Bandai card, Dragonite is shown using its antennae to discharge a Hyper Beam attack! Example: https://bulbapedia.bulbagarden.net/wiki/File:Bandai_Dragonite_card.jpg
One of the Pok√©mon Mansion journals states Mewtwo's birthday is February 6!
Mew is the only gender-unknown Pok√©mon species that is legitimately able to learn Captivate, which fails when used!
At 11:22AM on 14 July 2016, the official Barnes and Noble twitter account accidentally tweeted out an explicit picture featuring Mew with the caption 'Of Mice and Mew. #PokemonABook'!
Due to a programming error, Chikorita is not required in order to receive the Dex Diploma in Pok√©mon Ruby and Sapphire!
The leaves on Bayleef's neck are consistently described as having a spicy aroma. However, real bay leaves have a bitter and herbal taste, which is similar to thyme!
In Pok√©mon Gold and Silver only, Meganium has 5 petals on its neck, not 6!
Cyndaquil, Charmander, and their respective evolutionary lines have exactly the same base stats in the same distribution!
In addition to Typhlosion, Quilava shares its category with its evolved form and Entei: they are all known as the Volcano Pok√©mon! They are also both capable of learning Eruption!
Typhlosion and Togetic are the only Pok√©mon officially introduced in Generation II not to appear in the anime until the next generation!
In Gen II only, the spikes on Shiny Totodile's back are purple, not blue!
In episode 153 of the anime, Ash's Totodile falls in love with an Azumarill!
Croconaw is the starter Pok√©mon with the shortest level gap between evolutions (12 levels), evolving from Totodile at level 18 and into Feraligatr at level 30!
Croconaw has only one spike on its tail! ü•∫
Feraligatr reaches its final evolutionary form earlier than any other starter Pok√©mon, at level 30!
The shortening of '-gator'into '-gatr' in Feraligatr's name is a result of the ten-character limit on English Pok√©mon names in Generation II!
In the mainline series, Sentret is depicted standing on its tail in every game until Gen VI!
In Gen VIII, Sentret can only learn Trick as an egg move, but only when bred from a male Smeargle that has copied that move using Sketch!
Furret has exactly two whisker-like marks on either side of its face!
Hoothoot is pronounced 'hoot-hoot,' not 'hooth-oot!'
Hoothoot has a unique fade-in animation that is programmed into Pok√©mon Gold and Silver but goes unused!
Noctowl is the first Pok√©mon to appear as a Shiny in the anime!
Despite their category, 'Five-Star Pok√©mon,' Ledyba and Ledian's five spots are neither star-shaped nor are they arranged in a typical star pattern!

Ledyba and Ledian could not learn any Bug-type or Flying-type moves until Generation III! Their level up learnset did not contain any Bug-type moves until Generation IV or any Flying-type moves until Generation VII!
Despite multiple Pok√©dex entries describing its nocturnal behavior, wild Ledian are almost always encountered exclusively during the morning or daytime!

Ledian is the least represented Pok√©mon by GameFreak and The Pok√©mon Company, only having 2 official pieces of merchandice, 11 pokemon cards, and 5 appearances in the anime (one per episode)! (submitted by @MintKori)
Spinarak and its evolved form, Ariados, are the only known Pok√©mon capable of learning the move Toxic Thread!
Despite being based on a spider, Ariados only has four legs!
Ariados is one of the few Pok√©mon whose sprites in Gold, Silver, and Crystal are the same!
Crobat's color scheme is the reverse of Golbat's. This also applies to its Shiny variation!
Although Chinchou is shown to have the ability to walk on land in the anime, in the games, it can only be caught in water, and it lacks a footprint!
Chinchou and Lanturn are the only Electric-type Pok√©mon in the Water 2 Egg Group!
Lanturn shares its category with Ampharos; they are both known as the Light Pok√©mon!

Lanturn's Pok√©dex entry from Pok√©mon Gold describes it as being able to produce light visible from the surface of the ocean at some a depth of 3 miles. However, the amount of energy this would require is 10^35 times that available in the observable universe and would possibly result in a black hole many times the size of the current universe the instant it began to emit light (submitted by @15MinuteUpload)
Pichu's famoulsy subtle shiny was much more distinctive in Gen II!
Pichu has the lowest base stat total of all Electric-type Pok√©mon!
Pichu is the only Generation II Pok√©mon to be playable in the Super Smash Bros. series (though many others appear from Pok√© Balls)!
Cleffa shares its category with Staryu. They are both known as Star Shape Pok√©mon!
Cleffa, Igglybuff, and Morelull are all tied for the lowest base Speed stat of all Fairy-type Pok√©mon: 15!

Togepi is the second Generation II Pok√©mon (after Ho-Oh) to appear in the Kanto saga of the anime.
Togepi and Absol are the only non-Flying-type Pok√©mon that can have Super Luck as their Ability!
On the DVD scene selection screen from 'Mewtwo Strikes Back,' Togepi is listed as Pok√©mon #152!
Togetic and Typhlosion are the only Pok√©mon officially introduced in Generation II not to appear in the anime until the next generation!
Togetic and Blissey share a category; they are both known as the Happiness Pok√©mon! ü•∞
Togetic and Togekiss are the only Fairy-type Pok√©mon in the Flying Egg Group!

Xatu's male form features three stripes on its lower body, while its female form features two stripes!
In German, Mareep is known as Voltilamm (as in Volt + Lamb)!
Flaaffy's shiny didn't have a green ball on its tail until Gen III)!

An early design for Ampharos depicts it with a shorter neck that only had two rings instead of three! Example: https://bulbapedia.bulbagarden.net/wiki/File:Official_Pokemon_Fanbook_1997_Ampharos_Sprite.png

In its Gold and Silver artwork, Bellossom's body is colored blue instead of the usual green! This color is similar to its Shiny color in Generation II! Example: https://bulbapedia.bulbagarden.net/wiki/File:182Bellossom_GS.png
Despite its apparent connection to hula dancing, Bellossom is not native to the Alola region and must be transferred in from other regions! :(
Marill is referred to as 'Pikablu' on Topps' 'Pok√©mon the First Movie Trading Cards!' Example: https://bulbapedia.bulbagarden.net/wiki/File:The_first_movie_44.jpg

According to its Pok√©mon Silver Dex Entry, when Azumarill plays in water, it rolls up its elongated ears to prevent their insides from getting wet!
Sudowoodo was created by Ken Sugimori! It was created to serve as an obstacle in the overworld!
In Pok√©mon Scarlet and Violet, Artazon Gym Leader Brassius terastallizes Sudowoodo into a Grass Type, allowing it to finally achieve its dream of becoming a tree! ü•∫
In German, Politoed is called Quaxo!
Despite there being several frog-like Pok√©mon, Politoed is the only Pok√©mon in the ‚ÄúFrog‚Äù category!
An early design of Hoppip had no arms and legs and was dark-colored, resembling a black cat! (Example: https://archives.bulbagarden.net/media/upload/e/e8/Beta_Hoppip.png)
Skiploom's normal color and Shiny color is the reverse of its pre-evolution, Hoppip!
At 6.6 lbs. (3 kg), Jumpluff is the lightest Pok√©mon that has undergone two evolutions!
Aipom may vaguely reference the ahuizotl, a creature of Aztec mythology with monkey hands and a fifth human hand on its tail!

IN HGSS, Sunkern's Pok√©athlon performance stats can reach five stars in every stat! This is the highest possible stat total, shared only by Mew, Ditto, Origin Forme Giratina, and Arceus. Sunkern best legendary hands down. üòé
Sunflora's design is based on a Sunflower! üåª
Sunflora (that's me! üåª ) has been featured on 8 different cards since it debuted in the Neo Genesis expansion of the Pok√©mon Trading Card Game!

In Pok√©mon Crystal, a bug causes the capture formula for the Heavy Ball to incorrectly retrieve Sunflora's weight, giving it a +40 catch rate modifier! Unfortunately, however, Sunflora cannot be caught in the wild in Pok√©mon Crystal!
Yanma shares the same base Speed stat with its evolved form, Yanmega!
In Gen VII, despite being able to learn Leech Life through breeding, Yanma cannot learn it via TM!
Wooper has the lowest base Special Defense stat and the lowest base stat total of all Ground-type Pok√©mon: 25!
In Gen II only, the wavy pattern on the back of Shiny Quagsire is bright pink and the rest if its body is darker! In subsequent generations, its body is pink and the wavy pattern is dark purple!
Espeon is the only Eeveelution without a type advantage over another!
Espeon has blue inner ears in the games, but in the anime, they are often purple!
If one were to rearrange the Pok√©rap GS so all the Pok√©mon are in National Pok√©dex order, Espeon and Remoraid would remain in their respective positions in the song!
Espeon, Sunflora, and Volcarona all share the same category: they are all known as the Sun Pok√©mon!
Espeon and Umbreon in Pok√©mon Colosseum are the only starter Pok√©mon that you receive already evolved!

Due to the absence of a day-night cycle in FireRed and LeafGreen, in order for an Umbreon or Espeon to be obtained and added to the Pok√©dex in those games, an Eevee must be traded to Pok√©mon Ruby, Sapphire, and Emerald, evolved there, and then traded back, or else traded from Pok√©mon Colosseum or Pok√©mon XD: Gale of Darkness.
Umbreon was the only pure Dark-type Pok√©mon when it debuted in Gen II!
Several of Umbreon's Pok√©dex entries refer to ‚Äúpoisonous sweat,‚Äù which may be a holdover from the 1997 Nintendo Space World demo of Gold and Silver, where it was a Poison-type Pok√©mon!
In Gen II, Murkrow was not catchable until the postgame, on Routes 7 and 16 in Kanto at night!
Johtonian Slowking shares its category with Pyroar. They are both known as the Royal Pok√©mon!
Slowpoke cannot evolve into Slowking in Pok√©mon FireRed and LeafGreen before the player obtains the National Pok√©dex; its evolution will be interrupted!

Galarian Slowking is the only known Pok√©mon capable of learning the move Eerie Spell (other than Smeargle, of course), as well as the only known Pok√©mon that can have Curious Medicine as its (innate) Ability!
Misdreavus's first two anime appearances both involved members of the Legendary beasts trio: Raikou and Entei, respectively!
In Pok√©mon Colosseum, Misdreavus is the only Ghost-type Pok√©mon that can be snagged!
Misdreavus was the first pure Ghost-type Pok√©mon to be introduced, as well as the only one in Generation II!
Unown is the only Pok√©mon with a base stat total of 336!

Wobbuffet has the highest base HP stat of all Psychic-type Pok√©mon!
Based on the design of its tail, Wobbuffet may have been originally conceived as a pre-evolution for Girafarig!
Wobbuffet is one of fourteen Pok√©mon for which one can collect foreign Pok√©dex entriessay  in Pok√©mon Diamond and Pearl!
In Gen II, the ridges on Girafarig's back are white for both its normal and shiny sprites!

The route that Snubbull swarms on in Pok√©mon Diamond, Pearl, and Platinum is also its National Pok√©dex number: 209!

Scizor and Kleavor are the only Pok√©mon to not have their base stat total (500) changed upon evolving!
Scizor could only be caught in the wild starting in Gen VIII's SwSh DLC!
Shuckle has the highest base Defense and Special Defense stats of all obtainable Pok√©mon!
By using Power Trick, Shuckle can temporarily reach a base Attack stat of 230, which would be the highest of all Pok√©mon!
In Generation II, the first Shuckle holding a Berry in the player's party has a 1/16 chance to turn it into a Berry Juice after each battle!
Heracross is one of fourteen Pok√©mon that one could collect foreign Pok√©dex entries for in Pok√©mon Diamond and Pearl!
Heracross is the only Fighting-type Pok√©mon in the Bug Egg Group!
Sneasel has the highest base Speed stat (115) of all Pok√©mon that are capable of evolving!

Sneasel may be based on the kamaitachi (ÈéåÈº¨), a type of y≈çkai often represented as weasel demons with sickles on their front legs and sometimes understood as the cause of mysterious cuts on the skin, especially in cold weather!

In Pok√©mon Colosseum and Pok√©mon XD: Gale of Darkness, shiny Sneasel's feathers were green instead of gold!
Despite its fondness for honey in its Pok√©dex entries and even dropping Dazzling Honey, Dazzling Honey is not among the list of Teddiursa's preferred foods in Pok√©mon Legends: Arceus!
In Pok√©mon Gold and Silver, Teddiursa was exclusive to Gold Version, except for the Japanese and Korean releases of the games, in which it was exclusive to Silver Version!

Ursaring's number of claws has changed over time! In its original artwork, as well as from Pok√©mon Ruby and Sapphire up to Platinum, Ursaring has four visible claws; however, in the anime and HeartGold/SoulSilver onward, it has five claws. In the Generation II games, it has three claws!
Slugma and its evolution are the only Fire-type Pok√©mon with a serpentine body!
Slugma has the lowest base stat total of all Fire-type Pok√©mon (250)!
Magcargo is the only Rock-type Pok√©mon in the Amorphous Egg Group!

The typing of Swinub, Piloswine, and Mamoswine is the only combination weak to the types of all three starter Pok√©mon!
Swinub is one of the few Pok√©mon with the same sprite in both Gold and Silver!
Based on its footprint entry in the Pok√©dex in certain games, Piloswine is known to have hoovess!
Galarian Corsola and its evolution are the only Ghost-type Pok√©mon in both Water 1 and Water 3 Egg Groups!

In Gens II and III, Remoraid is also depicted on Mantine's front sprites!

In gens I through VI, Delibird only learns Present by level-up. Starting in Gen VII, it can learn Drill Peck at level 25!
In the EX Dragon Frontiers expansion, 'Mantine Delta Species' is a Lightning-type card!
According to the Pok√©dex, if it builds up enough speed swimming, Mantine can fly over 300 feet out of the water from the surface of the ocean! That's one whole football-sfield high!
Skarmory has the highest base Defense stat of all Flying-type Pok√©mon (140)!
Skarmory's number in the Johto Pok√©dex and New Unova Pok√©dex are the same: 203!

Skarmory's sprites in Gold and Silver featured a second tail above the first. (Example: https://bulbapedia.bulbagarden.net/wiki/File:Spr_2g_227.png) This extra tail is not featured in any artwork, and was removed in Crystal!
Despite being one of the few Dark-types introduced in Gen II, Haundour cannot be caught until the postgame on Kanto's route 7 at night!
Houndour has the lowest base Defense stat of all Fire-type Pok√©mon (30)!
The only five games so far in which Houndour can be captured by the player before viewing the end credits are Pok√©mon XD, Pok√©mon Platinum, Pok√©mon X, and Pok√©mon Scarlet and Violet!
Houndoom has three different sprites in each Gen II game and each Gen IV game!
Kingdra is the only Dragon-type Pok√©mon introduced in Generation II!
In Gen IV, wild Phanpy have a 5% chance of holding a Passho berry!
Donphan shares its category with Tyranitar. They are both known as the Armor Pok√©mon!

In the anime episode 'In Date Expectations' (episode 388 of the anime), a Shiny Donphan was the center of romantic attention for multiple male Donphan. Ash and his friends eventually helped one such Donphan to succeed and mate with the Shiny Donphan!
Porygon2 is the only Pok√©mon with a numeral in its name!

In the Generation II games, it is impossible to return a nicknamed Porygon2 to its species name, because numbers are not available for nicknames!
Porygon2 is the only non-fully evolved Pok√©mon that evolves into and from another Pok√©mon by trading!
Stantler's tail is brown, except in Gen III and Pok√©mon Crystal! In those games, its tail is white!
In Pok√©mon Stadium 2, Smeargle can have either blue, red, or green back and tail colors depending on its IV stats!
Tyrogue is the only Pok√©mon that created a shared evolution family between two Pok√©mon that were previously unrelated!

Hitmontop appears to be based on a spinning top and a capoeirista. Its idle animation from Generation VI onward depicts it performing a ginga, a basic technique in capoeira, and its name in Japanese, French, and Korean come from the word 'capoeira.' BRAZIL üáßüá∑ !
Hitmontop can learn the most priority moves of all Pok√©mon, with 14 increased priority moves and two decreased priority moves!

In Pok√©mon Gold and Silver, Smoochum is programmed to be able to learn Lovely Kiss through breeding, but no male Pok√©mon in the Human-Like Group can legitimately learn it to pass down as an Egg Move in those games!

The earliest that Elekid can be caught in the wild is in Pok√©mon Diamond and Pearl, where it can be found on Route 205 if the player has a copy of FireRed in the GBA slot of the Nintendo DS (dongle method)!
Magby has the lowest possible maximum Pok√©athalon stats of any Pok√©mon, only capable of reaching 3 stars in any of its five stats!
In Gen III, Miltank's shiny is extremely pale!
In Gen II, Miltank learns Rollout at level 34, but Whitney's Miltank knows it at level 20! Rigged!
Blissey is the only Pok√©mon whose base experience yield (608) is greater than its base stat total (540)!
A level 100 Dynamaxed Blissey with 31 IVs in HP, 252 EVs in HP, and a Dynamax Level of 10 has the highest HP of all Pok√©mon at 1428 HP!

Raikou is the only Pok√©mon in the anime whose image on the Pok√©dex was of stylized art rather than art by the series' character designer! (Example: https://bulbapedia.bulbagarden.net/wiki/File:Raikou_dex_entry_LoT.png)
Raikou's numbers in the National Pok√©dex and the Johto Pok√©dex are identical: 0243 and 243, respectively!
An unused event present in the data of Pok√©mon Gold and Silver (but removed from Crystal) allows for the player to obtain a level 40 Entei!
In Gold, Silver, and Crystal, playing Entei's cry in the Pok√©dex then switching to Suicune or Raikou before the cry ends causes a distortion in the cries of Suicune or Raikou!

Larvitar's sprite animation changes between Pok√©mon Diamond and Pearl and Pok√©mon Platinum, but its static sprite does not change!
Pupitar made its TCG debut in the Neo Discovery expansion!
No other Pok√©mon has the same type combination as Tyranitar!
Ho-Oh and Lugia are the only Legendary Pok√©mon that are game mascots that are not version-exclusives in their representative games!
Lugia's Shiny in Pok√©mon Stadium 2 is pale green rather than pink! (Example: https://twitter.com/KaffeineKaiju/status/1273476711292833792)
Ho-Oh is the first Generation II Pok√©mon to be shown in the anime!
In the Pok√©mon Gold and Silver Spaceworld '97 demo, Ho-Oh was a pure Flying-type legendary Pok√©mon!

Celebi's beta designs appear to draw inspiration from Kokopelli, a god of fertility and music from the cultures of some southwestern Native American peoples! (Example: https://twitter.com/DrLavaYT/status/1293193966649630720)
Shiny Swellow's colors and long tail feathers resemble those of the resplendent quetzal!

Manaphy and Ditto are the only Pok√©mon that are both able to breed yet unobtainable through breeding!
